content.webTitle: McLaren hold crisis meeting to stop F1 season slipping away

fields.headline: McLaren hold crisis meeting to stop F1 season slipping away
fields.bodyText: McLaren will hold a crisis meeting at their Woking headquarters on Tuesday morning to address the team's alarming collapse in form after a desperately disappointing British Grand Prix. McLaren have slumped from second to fourth in the constructors' championship, behind Red Bull, Ferrari and Lotus. They are 74 points behind Red Bull and are unlikely to pull that back in the remaining 11 races of the season. Jenson Button, who was 10th at Silverstone on Sunday and has scored only seven points from a possible 150 in the last six races, cast a grim assessment on the set up when he admitted: "If you put another driver in this car they would have a real shock." Lewis Hamilton, who started eighth on the grid at Silverstone and finished there, is also struggling, 37 points behind the championship leader Fernando Alonso despite some impressive form. After nine races, Hamilton has 92 points and Button 50; at the same stage last season both men were on 109. The outcome of Tuesday's meeting, and McLaren's ability to turn their season around, will impact on the futures of the team principal, Martin Whitmarsh, and his star driver Hamilton. Whitmarsh, in his fourth season in charge, has yet to deliver a drivers' or constructors' championship. Meanwhile, Hamilton will be out of contract at the end of the season and is already considering his options. McLaren's season has been dogged by a series of pit-lane mishaps. On Sunday their tyre changes were as slick as anyone's but they still have not come to terms with their lack of pace or the difficulties posed by the complex nature of their Pirelli tyres. According to Button, McLaren are now racing the midfield teams Williams, Sauber and Force India. He said: "We have a technical meeting on Tuesday, which is going to be sombre. We are just not quick enough. I don't know what has gone wrong." At the start of the season, in March, McLaren had the fastest car in the paddock and Button won the first race in Australia before coming second in the third in China. But results have fallen away badly since then and though Hamilton won the Canadian Grand Prix in Montreal last month, it proved something of a false dawn for the team.
